captions.text: We sang together.
We prayed together.

We listened quietly while Mother
read Bible and Book of
Mormon stories.

Father told us stories
out of his memory.

I still remember one
of those stories.

I found it recently while going
through a book he had
published some years ago.
Listen to it:

"An older boy and his young
companion were walking along a

road which led through
a field.

They saw an old coat and a badly
worn pair of men's shoes

by the roadside, and in the
distance they saw the owner
working in the field.

The younger boy suggested that
they hide the shoes, conceal

themselves, and watch the
perplexity on the owner's face
when he returned.
The older boy ...

thought that would
not be so good.
He said [this]

owner must be a very
poor man [from the
looks of his clothes].

So, after talking the matter
over, at his suggestion, they

concluded to try another
experiment.

Instead of hiding the shoes,
they would put a silver dollar

in each one and ... see what
the owner did when he
discovered the money.
So [that's what they did].

Pretty soon the man returned
from the field, put on his

coat, slipped one foot into a
shoe, felt something hard,

took it out and found
a silver dollar.
Wonder and surprise [shone]
upon his face.

He looked at the dollar again
and again, turned around and

could see nobody, then proceeded
to put on the other

shoe; when to his great
surprise he
found another dollar.
His feelings overcame him. ...

He knelt down and offered
aloud a prayer of

thanksgiving, in which he spoke
of his wife being sick

and helpless and his children
without bread. ...

He fervently thanked the Lord
for this bounty from unknown

hands and evoked
the [blessings]

of heaven upon those who had
given him this needed help.
The boys remained [hidden]

until he had gone." They had
been touched by his prayer and

felt something warm within
their hearts.

As they left to walk down the
road, one said to the other,

"Now really, don't you
have a good feeling?"

title: Lessons I Learned as a Boy

comments.text:
It is my prayer that some one reads this. Recently, I was looking for the 
meaning of Charity. You might be surprised that in Hebrew charity means 
DECENCY. In Hebrew the word for decency means grace. When God gives us 
grace, he imparts into us his decency. He helps us to be better people. 
This video proves this to be true. I Feel the spirit and know this to be 
true.﻿

comments.text:
1920 weeks pay was about $7.00, so for him to get about a day's pay it 
answered his prayers and helped pay for the medical expenses. when you pray 
for help you wont see a big hand come out of the sky, god helps people 
threw his followers. the person that feels out of nowhere to take a side 
road for no reason that is out of the way, to find a single mom struggling 
to carry her child and groceries on her long walk home, and answered her 
prayer to help her make it home. or when you leave in the winter and get 
the feeling/ thought I need to clean out my coat closet, so you gather all 
your unused coats, hats and scarves. and on the way to good will you see 
people that need them and answer their prayer. maybe you bring Two 
sandwiches to work one fills you up and you find out that someone that 
started to work there chose to give there children money to eat instead of 
having a meal, you have blessed there life and given them something that 
means a lot to them. To you it may be just a Tuesday but to them it may be 
a day that keeps them going, that they look back on for many years.
comments.author: bob dobbs

comments.text:
Spencer W Kimball is often quoted as saying, "The Lord answers our prayers, 
but it is usually through another person that he meets our needs.” I see it 
as extremely consistent with God's nature and character, as described 
throughout scripture, to bless or cure someone through the hands of 
another. Did the Lord bless this man or did the boys? I believe the Lord 
heard his pleading and inspired the older boy to be an instrument in 
blessing the man. From whom did the money come? At first glance it would 
seem it came from the boys. The Lord ways are higher than ours, His 
thoughts higher than ours. I do not believe all that we acquire is strictly 
from our own actions and abilities. Without the Lord, I am nothing. I love 
the parable of the talents because the talents, like our abilities, are 
given from the Lord. However, it is up to us to increase them with effort, 
judgement and exercise. I see the increase as coming from the Lord as well, 
but it is conditional upon our efforts. Sometimes the Lord "taketh away" as 
with the man working in the field here. In those times we pray, plead and 
do all in our power to bring about change. I have been the recipient of 
tender mercies like the one shown here many times. I feel deeply those who 
put the proverbial coins in my shoe were inspired from on high. Many of 
them did not know of our need or the perfection of their timing in coming 
to our rescue.
